messages: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (01:08): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: Which is easier for you - (1) defaulting the first/last stops if necessary, then correcting misordered stops, then defaulting any remaining stops, or (2) correcting misordered stops, then defaulting all remaining stops, with first being min(0,first specified stop) and last being max(100%,last specified stop)?
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:08): the former, since that's what I implemented

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:31): depends on the platform
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:31): but these builds install just like any other Firefox release
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:32): if you're on Windows, the easiest thing to do is to just download the ZIP, unzip it somewhere, and run firefox.exe
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:32): it's that simple
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:33): and make sure you're not already running a Firefox process
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:33): you may want to run "firefox.exe -P" and create a new profile for testing, that lets you run concurrently with an already-running Firefox
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:34): Don't you need to add -noremote or something?
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:34): yeah, you probably do
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:35): So it's not quite that simple ;-)

042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:35): running with a different profile can also be good because there is also a small chance that running a trunk build with your existing profile will cause problems when you go back to using your release version with that profile, although that has never happened to me, so the chances are very small indeed
